perturbation.original_text:
13. WARRANTIES

13.1 Each Party hereby represents and warrants to the other Party that:

13.1.1 all acts, conditions, authorisations, consents (including shareholder or parent company consents) and other things (including all licences
and permits) required in order to enable it lawfully to enter into, exercise its rights under or perform its obligations under this Agreement
and any other documents to be executed in connection with it or to authorise the same, have been duly done, fulfilled, obtained and
performed and are in full force and effect; and

13.1.2 neither the execution nor the delivery nor the performance of this Agreement will:

13.1.2.1 result in a breach of, or constitute a default under, or require the consent of a person under, any agreement or arrangement by
which it is bound;

13.1.2.2 conflict with its constitutional documents/result in a breach of any provision of its memorandum or articles of association; or

13.1.2.3 result in a breach of any law, regulation, order, judgement or decree of any court or government.

13.2 The express provisions of this Agreement are in place of corresponding warranties, conditions, terms, undertakings and obligations implied by
statute, common law, custom, trade usage, course of dealing or otherwise (including implied undertakings of satisfactory quality,
conformity with description and reasonable fitness for purpose), all of which are hereby excluded to the maximum extent permitted by law.
perturbation.changed_text:
13. WARRANTIES

13.1 Each Party hereby represents and warrants to the other Party that:

13.1.1 all acts, conditions, authorisations, consents required in order to enable it lawfully to enter into this Agreement have been obtained.

13.1.2 neither the execution nor the delivery nor the performance of this Agreement will conflict with its constitutional documents.

13.2 The express provisions of this Agreement are in place of corresponding warranties, conditions, terms, undertakings and obligations implied by
statute, common law, custom, trade usage, course of dealing or otherwise, all of which are hereby excluded to the maximum extent permitted by law.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the warranty that the agreement doesn't breach any laws or regulations, the contract now omits a crucial protection. This omission introduces the risk that a party could unknowingly enter into an agreement that violates laws in England and Wales, where the agreement is governed, such as regulations related to environmental protection or fair competition.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Various laws and regulations in England and Wales, including environmental protection laws, competition laws, and regulations related to fair business practices.

perturbation.original_text:
14. INDEMNITIES

14.1  Each Party agrees to indemnify, hold and save harmless the other Party, and defend at its own expense, from and against all suits, claims,
demands and liability of any nature and kind, including their cost and expenses, arising from:

14.1.1 the negligence; or

14.1.2 any intentionally wrongful acts or omissions, of the Party's own employees, agents, affiliates or subcontractors in connection with this
Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text:
14. INDEMNITIES

14.1  Each Party agrees to indemnify, hold and save harmless the other Party from and against all suits, claims,
demands and liability arising from the intentionally wrongful acts or omissions of its own employees in connection with this
Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the indemnity for negligence, the contract eliminates a standard protection against unintentional harm caused by a party. This introduces a legal risk because in English law (and other common law jurisdictions), negligence is a significant basis for liability. Removing this indemnity shifts the burden of risk onto the other party, potentially violating standards of fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General principles of tort law and contract law related to negligence and liability in England and Wales.

perturbation.original_text:
15. TERMINATION

15.1 Either Party may (without prejudice to its other rights) terminate this Agreement at any time by giving written notice to the other Party if:

15.1.1 the other Party becomes unable to pay its debts (within the meaning of section 123 (l)(e) or (2) of the Insolvency Act 1986), admits its
inability to pay its debts or becomes insolvent, or (ii) a petition is presented, an order made or a resolution passed for the liquidation
(otherwise than for the purposes of a solvent amalgamation or reconstruction), administration, bankruptcy or dissolution of the other
Party, or (iii) an administrative or other receiver, manager, trustee, liquidator, administrator or similar person or officer is appointed to the
other Party and/or over all or any part of the assets of the other Party, or (iv) the other Party enters into or proposes any composition or
arrangement concerning its debts with its creditors (or any class of its creditors) generally, or (v) anything equivalent to any of the events
or circumstances stated in (i) to (iv) inclusive occurs in any applicable jurisdiction; or

15.1.2 the other Party commits a material or persistent breach of the provisions of this Agreement (a "Breach"), provided that if the Breach is
remediable, the other Party shall be given thirty (30) days to remedy the Breach from receipt of the first Party's written notice specifying
the nature of the Breach and requesting that the same be remedied.
perturbation.changed_text:
15. TERMINATION

15.1 Either Party may (without prejudice to its other rights) terminate this Agreement at any time by giving written notice to the other Party if:

15.1.1 the other Party becomes unable to pay its debts, or (ii) a petition is presented for the liquidation of the other Party, or (iii) an administrative receiver is appointed to the
other Party and/or over all or any part of the assets of the other Party.
perturbation.explanation: By significantly limiting the conditions under which the agreement can be terminated due to insolvency or financial distress, the contract creates a high risk for the solvent party. This omission makes it harder for a party to protect itself from a failing business partner, potentially conflicting with principles of fair dealing and creating an unfair balance of power. The original terms offered protections aligned with standard commercial practice, whereas the modified terms unreasonably favor one party.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Principles of contract law related to fairness, good faith, and unconscionability in England and Wales.
